name: Techno-agnosticism
description: A 21st-century stance refusing to worship or demonize tech—judge it by results, not hype.

name: Critical AI Studies
description: A 21st-century field dissecting artificial intelligence’s social fallout—who wins, who loses?

name: Hyperconnectivity Theory
description: A 21st-century idea that constant online links—X, Zoom—rewire brains and societies, for better or worse.

name: Radical Localism
description: A 21st-century ideology doubling down on community control—global’s out, nearby’s in.

name: Computational Sociology
description: A 21st-century science crunching big data to map social trends—think X posts predicting riots.

name: Post-privacy Theory
description: A 21st-century take that privacy’s dead—cameras and trackers rule, so adapt or hide.

name: Techlash
description: A 21st-century ideology turning on Big Tech—too much power, too little soul, time to fight back.

name: Radical Uncertainty
description: A 21st-century philosophy embracing the unknown—plans fail, so roll with the chaos.

name: Green Capitalism
description: A 21st-century ideology betting markets can save the planet—profit meets solar panels.

name: Critical Surveillance Studies
description: A 21st-century theory exposing how cameras and algorithms cage us—privacy’s a myth now.

name: Data Sovereignty
description: A 21st-century ideology demanding control over your bits—nations and people vs. cloud giants.

name: Automation Anxiety
description: A 21st-century theory of dread—robots swipe jobs, leaving humans scrambling for meaning.

name: Eco-libertarianism
description: A 21st-century hybrid freeing nature via markets—less state, more green entrepreneurship.

name: Post-digital Humanism
description: A 21st-century philosophy keeping humanity’s heart alive in a world drowning in code.

name: Platform Socialism
description: A 21st-century ideology hijacking tech platforms—like Uber—for public good, not private gain.

name: Cyber-war Theory
description: A 21st-century study of digital battlegrounds—hacks and bots as the new bombs.

name: Critical Design
description: A 20th-century theory, thriving now, using weird objects to question tech’s march—think dystopian prototypes.

name: Commons-based Peer Production
description: A 21st-century ideology of shared creation—Wikipedia’s model, but for everything.

name: Techno-realism
description: A late-20th-century stance, loud now, cutting through tech hype with cold, hard skepticism.

name: Post-neoliberalism
description: A 21st-century ideology hunting for what’s next—markets plus something fairer, maybe.

name: Climate Realism
description: A 21st-century theory facing facts—warming’s here, adapt or sink, no utopia coming.

name: Behavioral Economics
description: A 20th-century science, big now, showing how we’re irrational—nudges beat logic in money games.

name: Digital Ethics
description: A 21st-century philosophy tackling online right and wrong—privacy, bots, and cancel culture.

name: Shock Doctrine
description: A 21st-century theory of crisis as a capitalist goldmine—disasters open doors for profit.

name: Alter-globalization
description: A 21st-century ideology tweaking globalism—fair trade and local vibes over corporate steamrollers.

name: Critical Internet Studies
description: A 21st-century field unpacking the web’s power—who controls it, who gets screwed?

name: Cyber-libertarianism
description: A 20th-century ideology, hot now, dreaming of a free net—no rules, just code and chaos.

name: Deliberative Democracy
description: A 20th-century idea, growing now, pushing talk over votes—citizens hash it out, not just check boxes.

name: Social Acceleration Theory
description: A 21st-century look at life speeding up—tech and time crush us, no pause button in sight.

name: Open Democracy
description: A 21st-century ideology cracking government wide—transparency and participation, no secrets.

name: Future Studies
description: A 20th-century science, thriving now, forecasting trends—climate, AI, whatever’s next.

name: Post-labor Theory
description: A 21st-century vision where work’s optional—automation frees us, if we don’t mess it up.

name: Steampunk
description: A 20th-century retro-fantasy, alive in 21st-century art—Victorian tech meets wild imagination.

name: Anti-surveillance Movement
description: A 21st-century rebellion dodging cameras and trackers—privacy’s worth the fight.

name: Critical Indigenous Studies
description: A 21st-century theory amplifying native voices—colonialism’s scars meet modern resistance.

name: Filter Bubble Theory
description: A 21st-century idea that algorithms trap us in echo chambers—X feeds you what you already like.

name: Green Anarchism
description: A 20th-century ideology, active now, smashing state and industry for a wild, free Earth.

name: Neuroeconomics
description: A 21st-century science blending brain scans and cash—why we buy dumb stuff.

name: Anti-consumerism
description: A 20th-century ideology, loud in the 21st, rejecting buy-buy-buy for simpler, saner living.

name: Radical Simplicity
description: A 21st-century lifestyle ideology stripping life to basics—less stuff, more peace.

name: Dark Enlightenment
description: A 21st-century fringe philosophy dumping democracy for tech-driven order—edgy and grim.

name: Social Ecology
description: A 20th-century theory, alive now, linking eco-woes to social hierarchies—fix one, fix both.

name: Eco-populism
description: A 21st-century ideology rallying the masses for green causes—people power meets planet love.

name: Digital Citizenship
description: A 21st-century ideology redefining rights and duties online—X isn’t just a playground.

name: Liberation Theology
description: A 20th-century faith, still kicking, where God sides with the poor—religion meets revolution.

name: Overton Window Theory
description: A 20th-century idea, big now, tracking how wild ideas—like UBI—go mainstream.

name: Citizen Science
description: A 21st-century movement where regular folks—like you—crunch data for breakthroughs.

name: Intersectional Environmentalism
description: A 21st-century ideology tying race, class, and climate—green wins need justice too.

name: Urban Informatics
description: A 21st-century science using data to decode cities—traffic, smog, and all.

name: Techno-aesthetics
description: A 21st-century theory of beauty in circuits—think sleek gadgets and glitch art.

name: Eco-technocracy
description: A 21st-century ideology where green experts steer the ship—tech nerds save the planet.

name: Post-democracy
description: A 21st-century theory that voting’s a sham—power’s elsewhere, in boardrooms and algorithms.

name: Critical Tourism Studies
description: A 21st-century look at travel’s dark side—selfies and resorts vs. locals and land.

name: Open Innovation
description: A 21st-century ideology tossing corporate walls—crowds and rivals co-build the next big thing.

name: Digital Labor Theory
description: A 21st-century idea that your likes and scrolls are unpaid work—tech firms cash in.

name: Green Urbanism
description: A 21st-century ideology greening cities—parks, bikes, and solar, not just concrete.

name: Post-humanitarianism
description: A 21st-century theory rethinking aid—tech and locals lead, not white saviors.

name: Critical Food Studies
description: A 21st-century probe into eats—power, culture, and who gets fed shape every bite.

name: Radical Wellness
description: A 21st-century ideology flipping self-care—health’s a right, not a luxury product.

name: Post-religion
description: A 21st-century theory of faith’s fade—spirituality’s personal, not pew-bound.

name: Critical Fashion Studies
description: A 21st-century look at clothes—sweatshops, trends, and identity stitch the story.

name: Eco-futurism
description: A 21st-century ideology blending green dreams with sci-fi—sustainable tomorrow, today.

name: Social Impact Theory
description: A 20th-century idea, big now, measuring how groups sway us—X mobs prove it.

name: Critical Heritage Studies
description: A 21st-century field asking whose past gets saved—museums aren’t neutral.

name: Radical Pedagogy
description: A 20th-century ideology, alive now, turning schools into freedom labs—teach to liberate.

name: Post-carbon Theory
description: A 21st-century vision of life after oil—energy’s new, society’s reborn.

name: Critical Public Health
description: A 21st-century theory digging into health’s politics—pandemics hit the poor hardest.

name: Radical Agroecology
description: A 21st-century ideology growing food with nature—corporations out, farmers in.

name: Digital Ecology
description: A 21st-century science of online ecosystems—think X as a jungle, not just a tool.

name: Post-globalization
description: A 21st-century theory of world ties fraying—local rises as global stumbles.

name: Critical Sports Studies
description: A 21st-century look at games—power, race, and cash behind every goal.

name: Radical Urbanism
description: A 21st-century ideology reimagining cities—people over profit, streets for all.
